awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards User Privacy in Outsourced Cloud Data Services
awd_abstract_narration:
The emergence of cloud computing brings a paradigm shift to the way that data is stored, accessed and utilized. Especially, outsourcing data to the public cloud enjoys unlimited resources with great economic savings for both data owners and users. However, user privacy concerns have been a major hurdle for the widespread adoption of the public cloud technology. Encryption techniques can protect the confidentiality of users' data, however, supporting effective data utilization such as search operations over encrypted data become a key challenge. Existing techniques are either too computationally expensive, or lack enough flexibility to be adopted by cloud users in practice. 
This project aims at protecting user privacy in the cloud. It develops the tools to provide privacy-assured, usable, and efficient data utilization services in outsourced cloud storage systems. Specifically, it tackles the above challenges by combining cryptography with information-retrieval techniques, and focuses on three aspects: (1) the design of novel keyword search schemes over encrypted data with rich functionalities, including ranked search and multi-keyword search; (2) the design of privacy-preserving search schemes over data that are represented using various structures, such as graphs; (3) new approaches for protecting user privacy in the mobile cloud setting. This research also includes a prototyping and experimentation plan. 
Ensuring user privacy is fundamental to the success of public cloud deployment. This project also develops curricula and teaches and supervises students. Materials of this project will be made available online as tutorials, software packages, and publications of general interest.

por.por_cntn:
User data privacy protection in the cloud computing era is a challenging yet crucial task. In this project, we tackle this problem by assuming that user data will be encrypted before outsourcing to the cloud, and we develop techniques that provide privacy-preserving, efficient, and usable data services to users based on the encrypted cloud data.

The main research problem we have addressed in the project is search over encrypted data.  Although user data are encrypted and stored in the server in the encrypted form, useful data services, such as search, have to be provided without violating user data privacy. We tackled this problem by devising new privacy-preserving search schemes over encrypted data that add new functionalities and enhance the performance of the existing searchable encryption schemes. Along this line, we combine knowledge from multiple domains, including cryptography, information retrieval, algorithms, optimization, and distributed computing. We proposed a number of new search algorithms that can provide rich search functions over encrypted data stored in the cloud. The proposed schemes are novel and provide new functionalities, including multi-keyword search, ranked search, multi-keyword ranked search, fuzzy search. Those schemes are based on symmetric cryptography and can be executed efficiently at the cloud server. We also developed multi-dimensional keyword search functions based on asymmetric cryptography, those functions including equality query, subset query, and range query. The developed new schemes support a much richer set of search functions, which were not supported as effectively or efficiently by prior art. The type of data considered in our research include text data, graph structured data, and sensitive genomic data.
